Unveiling the decisive role of surficial properties on CuO x /CeO2 catalysts during CO preferential oxidation Junfang Ding Writing – original draft Methodology Investigation Funding acquisition Formal analysis Data curation Conceptualization a 1 Changjin Xu Writing – original draft Methodology Investigation Funding acquisition Formal analysis Data curation Conceptualization b 1 Hao Chai Methodology Investigation a Xinyi Yao Formal analysis a Yang Hao Methodology Methodology Investigation a Yingkang Yang Methodology Investigation a Xiaomin Sun Formal analysis a Guilan Fan Software Resources a ⁎ Shanghong Zeng Writing – review & editing Validation Investigation Funding acquisition Formal analysis Data curation Conceptualization a ⁎ a College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Inner Mongolia University, Hohhot 010021, PR China College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Inner Mongolia University Hohhot 010021 PR China College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Inner Mongolia University, Hohhot, 010021, PR China b College of Pharmacy, Inner Mongolia Medical University, Hohhot 010110, PR China College of Pharmacy, Inner Mongolia Medical University Hohhot 010110 PR China College of Pharmacy, Inner Mongolia Medical University, Hohhot 010110, PR China ⁎ Corresponding authors. 1 Junfang Ding and Changjin Xu contributed equally to this work and should be considered co-first authors. The surficial properties of heterogeneous catalysts are vital in determining their catalytic performance. Herein, we take K-CuO x /CeO2 as a typical composite to unveil the decisive role of surficial properties on the adsorption strengths of reactants, configurations of intermediates and desorption of products during CO preferential oxidation. Results show that adding K initially has minimal effect, but too much drastically reduces catalytic performance. Detailed analyses indicate adding K to CuO x /CeO2 catalyst increases the surficial basic sites, which not only inhibits O2 activation and CO2 desorption, but also reduces surface defects, Cu+ species and hydroxy species. Such a vast difference in adsorption behavior and surface species in turn lead to the transformation of intermediates from carboxylates to carbonates. DFT calculations further reveal that the barrier of rate-determining step for CuO x /CeO2 catalyst in carboxyl path is lower than that of K-CuO x /CeO2 in carbonate path, thus rendering a higher catalytic activity of CuO x /CeO2. Graphical Abstract Keywords Surficial properties CO adsorption O2 activation CO2 desorption Reaction intermediates Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Heterogeneous catalysis plays a vital role in the chemical industry, as it can accelerate a chemical reaction to reach equilibrium and selectively promote a desirable reaction from a complex network of competing chemical reactions [1,2]. The rational design and synthesis of advanced catalysts are of great significance for understanding the reaction mechanism and the structure-activity relationship [3,4]. On the molecular level, the catalytic reaction takes place on the surface/interfaces of catalysts, where reactants are adsorbed and subsequently converted into target products that eventually desorbed [5,6]. The intermediates of catalytic reaction and performance of catalysts are governed by the geometric configuration and chemical bonding of substrate molecules on the surface, which can be controlled by the atomic and electronic structure of the surface/interface of catalysts [7,8]. Thus, investigating and unveiling the surface chemistry of solid catalysts is of great importance for the rational design of structures of advanced catalysts. Preferential CO oxidation in H2 feeds (CO-PROX), a model system of redox-type reactions, is a promising process to reduce CO to tolerable levels (below 10 ppm) of proton exchange membrane fuel cells (PEMFCs), thus speeding the practical application of hydrogen in petrochemical and clean energy industries [9,10]. The key to applying for CO-PROX is to design highly active and selective catalysts that operate well in a wide temperature window. To date, extensive efforts have been devoted to optimizing interfacial/surficial structure with a hope to achieve high CO conversion. It has been found that the modification of alkali metals over nano-catalysts at a proper ratio can greatly enhance the catalytic performance of CO oxidation [11–13]. The enhancement of catalytic performance by doping alkali metals has been explained with several possibilities. Kuriyama and co-workers suggested that the introduction of potassium in Pt/Al2O3 catalysts not only weakens the interaction between CO and Pt, but also changes the CO adsorption site, thus enhancing the activity of CO-PROX [14]. While in the Pt-K/Fe-mordenite zeolite system, the addition of K weakens the adsorption of H2 and strengthens the adsorption of CO on Pt sites, where CO can be selectively and effectively converted [15]. Further, as reported in CuO x -CeO2 composites, the addition of K with an appropriate amount favors the dispersion of ceria, the synergistic effect between CuO and CeO2 and the formation of Cu+ species, which is crucial to CO-PROX catalytic performance [16,17]. Despite extensive research on the influence of alkali metals in CO-PROX reactions, there is still ongoing debate and ambiguity surrounding their exact effects on reactant adsorption strengths, intermediate configurations and product desorption. Herein, nanospheres-like CuO x /CeO2 and nanorods-like CuO x /CeO2 with different levels of K decoration were synthesized to investigate the exact effect of alkali metals (K) and surficial properties on the adsorption strengths of reactants, the configurations of intermediates and the desorption of products for CuO x /CeO2 based catalysts during CO-PROX reaction. By combining operando characterization and density functional theory (DFT) calculations, it reveals that the addition K to the CuO x /CeO2 catalyst increases the number of surficial basic sites, which not only inhibit O2 activation and CO2 desorption, but also reduces the surface defects, Cu+ species and adsorbed hydroxy species, resulting the intermediates transforming from carboxylates to carbonates. Owing to the facts that the barrier of rate-determining step for CuO x /CeO2 catalyst in the carboxyl path is lower than that of K-CuO x /CeO2 in the carbonate path, thus ensuring that CuO x /CeO2 had a higher catalytic activity. The current findings clarify the effects of surficial properties on the CO adsorption, oxygen activation and CO2 desorption of CuO x /CeO2 based catalysts and reveal their influence on the dominant CO-PROX reaction pathway, which will shed light on the design of advanced catalysts with excellent performance. 2 Experimental details 2.1 Materials Cerium nitrate hexahydrate (Ce(NO3)3·6H2O, AR), copper nitrate hydrate (Cu(NO3)2·3H2O, AR), alcohol (CH3CH2OH, 99.9 %) and glycol (HOCH2CH2OH, 99.9 %) were purchased from Tianjin FengChuan Chemical Research Institute (Tianjin, China). Sodium hydroxide (NaOH) and potassium nitrate (KNO3) was obtained from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co. Ltd (China). Glacial acetic acid (CH3COOH, 99.9 %) was purchased from Tianjin BeiLian Fine Chemical Development Institute (Tianjin, China). All the chemicals and reagents were commercially available and directly used without purification. 2.2 Synthesis of K-CuO x /CeO2-NS and K-CuO x /CeO2-NR catalysts In a typical synthesis, 2.0 g of Ce(NO3)3·6H2O was added to the mixed solution of 2 mL of deionized water, 2 mL of CH3COOH and 52 mL of glycol. After stirring for 30 min, the suspension was sealed into a Teflon-lined steel autoclave and reacted at 180 °C for 200 min. The product was collected by centrifugation, washed with deionized water and alcohol several times, and then dried at 60 °C overnight to obtain CeO2 nanospheres (CeO2-NS). Subsequently, 0.5 g of CeO2-NS and appropriate amounts of KNO3 were slowly added to 30 mL of Cu(NO3)2·3 H2O precursor solution. The mixture was stirred for 12 h, dried at 80 °C in a vacuum, and calcined at 500 °C for 2 h under an air atmosphere. the resulting catalysts were denoted as δK-CuO x /CeO2-NS (δ representing the content of K). For comparison, the CuO x /CeO2-NS was prepared using the same procedure without adding KOH. Additionally, aqueous solutions of Ce(NO3)3·6H2O (0.87 g, 5 mL) and NaOH (8.4 g, 35 mL) were dissolved in deionized water at room temperature. Then, the NaOH solution was added dropwise to precursor solution of Ce(NO3)3·6H2O under vigorously stirring. The mixture was sealed into a Teflon-lined steel autoclave and reacted at 100 °C for 24 h. Afterward, the product was collected by centrifugation, and then washed and dried to obtain the CeO2 nanorods (CeO2-NR). Finally, the δK-CuO x /CeO2-NR catalysts were synthesized through the same preparative route as the CuO x /CeO2-NS above. Analogously, the CuO x /CeO2-NR was also prepared without introducing K for comparative study. 2.3 Characterization and catalysis test Details on structural characterization and catalytic reactions to evaluate the catalytic performance of synthesized samples are included in the Supporting Information file. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic performance CO-PROX was carried out as a model catalytic reaction to investigate the effect of alkaline properties on the catalytic performance of the typical CuO x /CeO2 catalysts. Fig. 1a shows the CO-PROX activity profile of the δK-CuO x /CeO2-NS (δ = 0, 1 %, 2 %) catalysts. Overall, CO conversion for all samples increased continuously with reaction temperature until the CO conversion reached the maximum, and CO2 selectivity gradually decreased with reaction temperature owing to the competitive oxidation reaction of H2 and CO. CuO x /CeO2-NS exhibits the much better catalytic activity than the δK-CuOx/CeO2-NS (δ = 1 %, 2 %) catalysts. Meanwhile, the CuO x /CeO2-NS maintained excellent stability over a period of 12 h (Fig. S1). The T10 %, T50 % and T100 % of CuO x /CeO2-NS are 56, 74 and 95 °C, respectively (Fig. 1c). Comparatively, adding 1 % and 2 % of K in the preparation process, the catalytic activities decrease dramatically. The T10 %, T50 % and T100 % of 1 %K-CuO x /CeO2-NS and 2 %K-CuO x /CeO2-NS increased to 76, 117, 155 °C and 127, 156, 195 °C, respectively ( Table 1). Especially for 2 %K-CuO x /CeO2-NS sample, it shows non-detectable catalytic activity until the temperature is above 115 °C. Dongil et al. reported that the CO conversion shows a volcanic curve with K content in Cu(K)-CeO2/CNT system and Cu(K1)-CeO2/CNT behaved best [16,17]. To further optimize the K content, a series of δK-CuO x /CeO2-NS (δ = 0.05 %, 0.125 %, 0.25 %) catalysts with low K content have been synthesized using the same process. Fig. 1b compares the CO conversion and the CO2 selectivity of CuO x /CeO2-NS and K-modified δK-CuO x /CeO2-NS (δ = 0.05 %, 0.125 %, 0.25 %) catalysts. It can be clearly seen that CO conversion over CuO x /CeO2-NS sample is higher than 0.25 %K-CuO x /CeO2-NS at low temperature. Further reducing the K content to 0.125 % and 0.05 %, catalytic performance of δK-CuO x /CeO2-NS (δ = 0.05 %, 0.125 %) is comparable to that of CuO x /CeO2-NS, which all could achieve 100 % CO conversion at 95 °C. To obtain the intrinsic activities of the δK-CuO x /CeO2-NS and to evaluate their catalytic performance, turnover frequencies (TOFs) of above catalysts have been calculated. As presented in Fig. 1d, TOFs of δK-CuO x /CeO2-NS catalysts showed the same trend as its CO conversion. That is, the catalytic performance of CuO x /CeO2-NS remained almost after modified by a small amount of K, and if continuously increasing the K, its catalytic performance decreased dramatically. This phenomenon is different from that reported in literatures that the addition of K significantly enhances the catalyst performance at Pt/Al2O3 and CuO/CeO2 systems [14,17,18]. 3.2 Morphology and structure To investigate the changes of morphologies and structure features for CuO x /CeO2-NS after modifying K, XRD Rietveld refinement, SEM, TEM and HRTEM were performed. As shown in Fig. S2, all the characteristic diffraction peaks of δK-CuO x /CeO2-NS (δ = 0, 0.05 %, 0.125 %, 0.25 %, 1 %, 2 %) catalysts match well with JCPDS card No. 65–5923 for cubic fluorite-type CeO2, and no diffraction peaks of copper species and potassium species are detected on these catalysts, possibly due to the high dispersion or the low loading beyond the limitation of XRD detection. The average crystallite size of CeO2 in δK-CuO x /CeO2-NS catalysts was calculated using Scherrer formula based on the FWHM of CeO2 (111) peak and the results were summarized in Table 1. The average crystallite size of CeO2 in δK-CuO x /CeO2-NS (δ = 0, 0.05 %, 0.125 %, 0.25 %) is about 5 nm. As K content increased to 1 % and 2 %, the particle size of CeO2 increased slightly. In addition, the results of XRD refinement shown in Fig. 2a and b indicate that the unit cell parameters of CeO2 in CuO x /CeO2-NS and 2 %K-CuO x /CeO2-NS samples are almost the same. Considering that the radius of K+ (1.51 Å) is larger than that of Ce4+ (0.907 Å), the CeO2 unit cell parameters would expand if K+ was incorporated into the CeO2 lattice. Thus, it can be inferred that K species are adsorbed on the surface rather than doped into the CeO2 lattice in the 2 %K-CuO x /CeO2-NS sample. This result was further verified by Raman spectra, as shown in Fig. 2c and Fig. S3. For all δK-CuO x /CeO2-NS catalysts, only a strong band at about 446 cm−1 related to the F2 g symmetrical stretching vibration mode of metal-doped CeO2 in a fluorite structure is observed [19,20]. Owing to the valence imbalance between K+ and Ce4+, a band associated with oxygen vacancies should be observed in K-CuO x /CeO2-NS catalysts if K+ was doped into the CeO2 lattice. Morphologies of the samples were characterized by SEM and TEM. As shown in Fig. 2d, g and Fig. S4, the CuO x /CeO2-NS sample has a spherelike shape with average sizes around 130 nm, which is composed of small nanoparticles with a crystallite size of 4–6 nm. Morphology and diameter of nanospheres are maintained after modifying K. A HRTEM image of the region I and region II for CuO x /CeO2-NS sample in Fig. 2e shows three sets of symmetry diffraction spots, which can be indexed to the crystal planes (111) and (100) of CeO2. Similar to CuO x /CeO2-NS sample, the sample 2 %K-CuO x /CeO2-NS also showed the exposed facet (111) and (100) of CeO2, since HRTEM image and FFT pattern in Fig. 2h for 2 %K-CuO x /CeO2-NS are the same as those for CuO x /CeO2-NS in Fig. 2e. The interplanar spacing related to CuO x species was not found in the above two samples, possibly due to the high dispersion of CuO x , in agreement with the XRD results. TEM elemental mapping analysis suggests that a uniform distribution of CuO x over the CeO2 support was achieved in CuO x /CeO2-NS sample (Fig. 2f). Upon addition K, as shown for 2 %K-CuO x /CeO2-NS samples in Fig. 2i, cerium, copper, oxygen and potassium are homogeneously distributed across the whole nanospheres, implying successful modification of potassium species on the surface of the sample. Based on the above analysis, it can be inferred that modifying K did not change the exposed facets of CeO2. Thus, exposed facet is not a major factor in affecting its CO-PROX performance as described above for the samples CuO x /CeO2-NS and 2 %K-CuO x /CeO2-NS. 3.3 Chemical states, surficial species and alkaline properties To further illuminate the valence state and their relative abundance on the K-CuO x /CeO2-NS catalyst surface, XPS analysis was conducted. As shown in Fig. 3a, the Ce 3d spectra of all K-CuO x /CeO2-NS samples were deconvoluted into five pairs of peaks: two pair peaks centered at 885.0 eV, 903.1 eV and 880,8 eV, 890.6 eV, labeled as α, α′ and β, β′, are related to Ce 3d5/2 and 3d3/2 of Ce3+; another three pairs of peaks at 882.5 eV, 900.8 eV, and 888.2 eV, 907.4 eV, and 897.9 eV, 916.4 eV are associated with v, u, v’, u’, and v”, u” of Ce4+, respectively [21,22]. The concentrations of Ce3+ are calculated based on the fitting results of XPS and the results are summarized in Fig. 3d. The Ce3+ concentration is slightly decreased after K modification, especially for 1 %K-CuO x /CeO2-NS and 2 %K-CuO x /CeO2-NS samples. The transformation from Ce4+ to Ce3+ is generally accompanied by the generation of Frenkel-type oxygen vacancies, which is beneficial to activate surface oxygen species [23]. Fig. 3b displays Cu 2p XPS spectra of all K-CuO x /CeO2-NS samples. The characteristic peaks in a range of 931.8–933.5 eV are assigned to Cu+/0 species [24,25]. The peaks located at 933.8 eV, accompanied with an intense shake-up satellite peak, are identified as Cu2+ species [26]. Two peaks at 931.8 and 951.8 eV, associated with Cu 2p 3/2 and 2p 1/2 of Cu+/0 species, observed in all K-CuO x /CeO2-NS samples. Additionally, the weak satellite shake-up peaks observed in all samples suggest the presence of mixed valences of Cu2+ and Cu+/0 in the catalyst. Owing to the almost same binding energies existed in Cu+ and Cu0 2p photoelectron peaks, it is difficult to distinguish them in Cu 2p spectra. For this reason, Cu Auger spectra with a big separation for Cu+ and Cu0 were performed to determine the valence state of reduced copper species on the surface. As shown in Fig. 3g, a broad Auger line at about 917 eV, originated from an overlap between Cu+ and Cu2+, has observed in CuO x /CeO2-NS and 2 %K-CuO x /CeO2-NS samples [27]. Moreover, the kinetic energy of CuO x /CeO2-NS shifted towards the lower kinetic energy side when comparing to that for 2 %K-CuO x /CeO2-NS sample, implying the existence of more Cu+ species on the surface of CuO x /CeO2-NS. The concentration of Cu+ was calculated according to the area of fitting peaks, and the results are summarized in Fig. 3e. The relative content of Cu+ is somewhat higher in the CuO x /CeO2-NS sample in comparison to δK-CuO x /CeO2-NS (δ = 0.25 %, 1 %, 2 %), which further indicates modifying K slightly decreases Cu+ on the surface. As the reaction occurred in a H2-rich environment, the concentration of reduced copper species in the used catalysts increased compared to fresh catalysts (Fig. S5). However, the relative order of the Cu+/Cu2+ ratio remained unchanged post-reaction. It is commonly believed that Cu+ is the main active sites for CO adsorption and oxidation [28,29]. Thus, a large number of Cu+ species on CuO x /CeO2-NS surface are thought to be one of the reasons for the above distinct performance between CuO x /CeO2-NS and δK-CuO x /CeO2-NS (δ = 0.25 %, 1 %, 2 %) samples. The XPS spectra of O 1s are present in Fig. 3c. For δK-CuO x /CeO2-NS (δ=0, 0.05 %, 0.125 %), two peaks were observed at the binding energies of ∼529 and ∼531 eV, which is assigned to the surface lattice oxygen (O1) and the surface adsorbed oxygen (O2), respectively [23,29]. In addition to above two peaks, another peak at the binding energies of ∼533 eV, associated with oxygen of surface carbonates (O3), is detected for δK-CuO x /CeO2-NS (δ = 0.25 %, 1 %, 2 %) samples [30]. The corresponding content of oxygen species was calculated according to the fitting results of XPS, and the results are shown in Fig. 3f. Obviously, the concentration of surface adsorbed oxygen (O2) and surface oxygen in carbonates (O3) increased with the content of K. This phenomenon indicates that K modification enhances adsorption of some small molecules. The existence of the adsorbed carbonate species in C 1s spectra for 2 %K-CuO x /CeO2-NS sample further verified the above conclusion (Fig. 3h). In addition, it can be seen from the FT-IR spectra that with the increase of K content, the intensity of the carbonate-related peak located at 1385 cm−1 gradually increases, while the intensity ratio of IOH/IM-O (M = metal) gradually decreases (Fig. 3i Fig. S6 and Table 1) [31,32]. This observation suggests that the surficial active sites are largely occupied by carbonates in δK-CuO x /CeO2-NS (δ = 0.25 %, 1 %, 2 %) samples, resulting in a decrease of hydroxy species adsorbed on samples surface. As reported in literatures, hydroxyl groups on the catalyst surface play a vital role in determining the CO chemisorption and oxidation [5]. As a consequence, it is expected that the catalytic pathway of these samples with distinct surface species could be greatly altered, especially for CuO x /CeO2-NS and 2 %K-CuO x /CeO2-NS samples. 3.4 Alkaline properties, CO adsorption and CO2 desorption The adsorption, activation and desorption of CO/CO2 are closely related to the alkaline sites on the surface. CO2-TPD and DRIFTS were performed to investigate the surficial alkaline properties, and the relationship of alkaline properties, CO adsorption, CO2 desorption and catalytic performance was discussed. Fig. 4c depicts the CO2-TPD profiles of the three representative samples, which are divide into three regions. The peaks in the temperature range of 30–200 °C, 200–400 °C, and 400–600 °C are attributed to weak, medium, and strong basic sites associated with Brønsted hydroxyl groups, acid-base Lewis pairs and low coordinated O2-, respectively [33,34]. In the case of the CuO x /CeO2-NS sample, two diverse basic sites are existed. One is medium basic sites located at about 280 °C and the majority is weak basic sites centered at 74 °C. With the introduction of K, the number of weak and medium basic sites increases, accompanied by the generation of new strong basic sites (Fig. 4c). Meanwhile, it should be noted that the low temperature CO2 desorption peak was progressively moved to higher temperatures, i.e. 76.5 °C and 79.2 °C, for increasing K amounts of 1 wt% and 2 wt%, respectively. As expected, the increase of basic sites and basic strength suppress the desorption of CO2, which facilitated the formation of a stable carbonate specie, thus resulting the such bad performance of 1 %K-CuO x /CeO2-NS and 2 %K-CuO x /CeO2-NS catalysts (Fig. 1). This conclusion is also supported by literature [35], which indicates that low concentrations of potassium induce the dissociation of carbon dioxide. At higher potassium contents, CO2 is converted or disproportionated into CO and carbonate. In addition to CO2 desorption, surface species and alkaline properties of catalysts will also exert an influence on the CO adsorption. As seen in Fig. 4a, b and Fig. S7, under 1 vol% CO/He gas flow, only a strong characteristic band located at about 2100 cm−1 was observed for δK-CuO x /CeO2-NS (δ = 0, 0.05 %, 0.125 %, 0.25 %, 1 %) catalysts. Further increasing K content to 2 %, another band at about 2170 cm−1 appeared. For copper-based catalysts, the bands centered at 2200–2140 cm−1 and 2140–2100 cm−1 are assign to the adsorptions of CO on Cu2+and Cu+ sites, respectively [36,37]. Above observation suggests that the Cu+ on the surface is main adsorption sites for CO in δK-CuO x /CeO2-NS (δ = 0, 0.05 %, 0.125 %, 0.25 %, 1 %) catalysts, and adsorption sites for CO in 2 %K-CuO x /CeO2-NS catalysts are Cu+ and Cu2+, which is in accordance with the XPS analyses. Carefully comparison of the Cu+-CO vibrations for these δK-CuO x /CeO2-NS samples, two striking changes that have to be mentioned. The first one is that the band of Cu+-CO for 2 %K-CuO x /CeO2-NS shifted towards lower frequencies when compared to that of CuO x /CeO2-NS sample. Such a shift reflects an increased back-donation of electrons from Cu to CO, indicating that adsorption of CO on CuOx sites had been enhanced to some extent [38]. The second one is the behaviors of CO desorption: after introduction of N2, CO adsorbed on Cu+ sites were desorbed rapidly in 14 min for CuO x /CeO2-NS, while for the 2 %CuO x /CeO2-NS, adsorbed CO on Cu+ sites could not be completely desorbed even in 20 min. These observations agreed with literature that the increase content of potassium in catalysts enhances the adsorbed strength of CO, thus stabilizing the CO without dissociation and forming the potassium compound [39]. It is generally accepted that in CO-PROX reaction, too strong CO adsorption would not only increase the barrier of the reaction, but also inhibit the adsorption and activation of CO [40,41]. Thus, the enhanced adsorbed strength of CO and CO2 is considered as the main reason to such distinctions in catalytic performance for these K-CuO x /CeO2-NS samples. 3.5 Redox behavior and lattice oxygen activation Catalytic performance of CO oxidation for CuO x -CeO2 based catalyst is closely depending on the ability to provide active oxygen during the reaction process [42]. Thus, H2-TPR was performed to investigate the effect of surface species and alkaline properties on the extraction and activation of oxygen species. As shown in Fig. 5a, two multiple-step reduction peaks were observed below 400 °C in the TPR profiles for K-CuO x /CeO2-NS samples. The first peak (α) at low temperature is associated with the reduction of most easily reducible CuO x species which are highly dispersed and interacts strongly with CeO2 [27]. And the second peak (β) at relatively a high temperature is attributed to the reduction of isolated CuO x that has a weak interaction with CeO2 or the bulk CuO with large sizes [28]. It is noteworthy that both reduction peaks of α and β for δK-CuO x /CeO2-NS (δ=1 %, 2 %) shift to higher temperature in comparison with the CuO x /CeO2-NS catalyst (Fig. 5b and c). Considering that the reduction process is related to the relaxation of the oxygen-metal bond, H2-TPR results indicate that the addition of K will significantly impede the extraction of lattice oxygen species. These effects can be reasonably explained by the two primary factors: (i) the presence of K species increase the electron density of the catalyst surface and inhibit the reducibility of surface oxygen; and (ii) physically block the surface CuO x nanoparticles weaken the hydrogen spillover capability. In addition to the strong reduction peaks below 400 °C, three peaks located at 453, 770 and 850 °C are also observed in the CuO x /CeO2-NS sample. The peaks in the temperature range of 400–600 °C and 600–900 °C is assigned to the reduction of surface ceria and bulk ceria, respectively [43]. Upon addition K in the samples, the reduction peak of surface ceria disappeared, and only a broad reduction peak located at about 780 °C is observed. It appears that K is unfavorable to accelerate the extraction of surface lattice oxygen species, most likely due to the weakened interaction between CuO x and CeO2. Combined with the above analysis, it is concluded that the extraction and activation of oxygen species closely depend on the surface species and alkaline properties of samples, and the addition of K will observably impede the extraction of oxygen species, which would result a worse catalytic performance in these samples containing K. 3.6 Mechanism of CO-PROX reaction To further provide insights into the mechanistic differences governing the catalytic performance of K-CuO x /CeO2-NS catalysts with different surface species and alkaline properties, in situ DRIFTS spectra were carried out under CO-PROX reaction conditions. As presented in Fig. 6, DRIFTS spectra are mainly divided into two characteristic regions. One zone in a range 2400–2000 cm−1 is mainly associated to the vibrations of CO2 and Cun+-CO species; and the other region below 1800 cm−1 is related to the intermediates of carbonates, carboxylates and formates [28]. A characteristic band at about 2098 cm−1 was observed in the CuO x /CeO2-NS, which is associated with the adsorptions of CO on Cu+ [44]. Besides this one, another band at about 2193 cm−1, related to the adsorptions of CO on Cu2+, also found in 2 %CuO x /CeO2-NS sample [36]. This observation corresponds to the earlier temporal DRIFTS spectra that the main adsorption sites for CO in the CuO x /CeO2-NS are Cu+, while the CO adsorbed sites in 2 %K-CuO x /CeO2-NS catalysts are Cu+ and Cu2+. In addition to the CO adsorption, the alkaline properties of catalysts also exert great influence on the intermediates and the reaction path. As shown in Fig. 6b, the main intermediates of CuO x /CeO2-NS sample are carboxylates which located at about 1547 cm−1 [45,46]. Contrastively, carbonates at about 1348 and 1393 cm−1 are main intermediates for the 2 %K-CuO x /CeO2-NS sample [47]. The transition of reaction intermediates is mainly caused by the change of CO adsorption sites, CO adsorption strength and CO2 adsorption strength, which is determined by the surface species and alkaline properties of catalysts. It is acknowledged that the accumulation of carbon-containing species such as carbonate on surface of catalysts would decrease the activity owing to the blockage of active sites [48]. As expected, the negative effect of K on the catalytic performance for these δK-CuO x /CeO2-NS (δ = 0.25 %, 1 %, 2 %) catalysts has been verified (Fig. 1). On the basis of above results, two reaction mechanisms have been proposed by density functional theory (DFT) calculations. For CuO x /CeO2 sample, the carboxyl route was suggested as the main pathway to produce gaseous CO2 ( Fig. 7), as verified by in situ DRIFTS spectra. Firstly, the surficial hydroxy group reacts with CO adsorbed on CuO x and generates carboxyl intermediates and hydroxyl vacancy (VOH) with a barrier of 2.72 eV. Subsequently, the VOH is filled by OOH species with introduced oxygen molecules and CO2 is generated by the deprotonation of the carboxyl intermediates. Then, OOH species reacts with the second adsorbed CO, generating another CO2 molecules with an activation barrier of 5.14 eV (Fig. 7). Finally, the CuO x /CeO2 surface is recovered after CO2 desorption. OH participation in this path is further confirmed by an isotopic oxygen tracing experiment. After introducing CO and 18O2 to CuOx/CeO2, C16O16O is released prior to C16O18O (Fig. S8), indicating the participation of OH species in the catalyst, and then, the oxygen species derived from gas-phase O2. For comparison, CO oxidation over K-CuO x /CeO2 mainly follows carbonates route, as shown in Fig. 7. Molecular O2 preferentially adsorbs on the oxygen vacancy (VO), then two O* atoms adsorbed on the surface successively react with CO* or CO (g) to release two CO2 finish the reaction. During this reaction path, the barrier of rate-determining step (the formation of the first CO2 molecules) for K-CuO x /CeO2 catalyst is 5.85 eV, higher than that of CuO x /CeO2 (5.14 eV), which demonstrates that the carboxyl path is favorable for CO oxidation, thus rendering CuO x /CeO2 shown a higher catalytic activity of CO oxidation. To further illustrate the effect of surface species and alkaline properties is independent of the exposed plane, a series of δK-CuO x /CeO2 (δ = 0, 0.05 %, 0.125 %, 0.25 %, 1 % and 2 %) with nanorods morphology were synthesized (Fig. S9). As shown in Fig. S10, all the characteristic diffraction peaks of K-CuO x /CeO2-NR samples match well with CeO2, and no diffraction peak of copper species and potassium species is detected. This observation is possibly owing to the high dispersion of CuO x and low content of potassium species. Similar to K-CuO x /CeO2-NS samples, CuO x /CeO2-NR exhibits the much higher catalytic activity than the δK-CuO x /CeO2-NR (δ = 1 %, 2 %) catalysts (Fig. S11). Further reducing the K content to 0.25 %, 0.125 % and 0.05 %, the catalytic performance of δK-CuO x /CeO2-NR increased with the decreased K content and reached a maximum until the K content decreases to 0.05 %, which catalytic performance is comparable to that of CuO x /CeO2-NR (Fig. S11). TOFs of these K-CuO x /CeO2-NR catalysts showed the same trend as their CO conversion. This phenomenon gives credible evidence that the effect of alkali metals and surficial properties on catalytic performance is independent of the exposed plane. 4 Conclusions In summary, a series of K-CuO x /CeO2 composites were synthesized and the effect of surface species and alkaline properties on CO-PROX reaction was systematically investigated. Catalytic results show that catalytic performance of CuO x /CeO2 composites remained almost after modified by a small amount of K, and if continuously increasing K, its catalytic performance decreased dramatically. Based on comprehensive structural characterization results and DFT calculations, the influence of alkali metals on CO-PROX catalytic performance mainly summarized to three aspects: (i) potassium disperses across the catalyst surface, which elevates surface basicity and enhances the adsorption strength of CO and CO2, thus inhibiting CO activation and CO2 desorption; (ii) the introduction of potassium in CuO x /CeO2 composites reduces the surface defects, Cu+ species, adsorbed hydroxy species, which suppresses the intrinsic reducibility and CO adsorption sites; (iii) the distinction of basic sites, adsorption behavior and surface species drives the transformation of intermediates from carboxylate to carbonate. DFT calculations suggest the barrier of rate-determining step for CuO x /CeO2 catalyst is lower than that of K-CuO x /CeO2, thus leading to CuO x /CeO2 had a higher catalytic activity of CO oxidation. These in-depth studies using well-defined CuO x -CeO2 nanostructures combined with in-situ characterization established the relationship between surficial alkali metal and CO adsorption, oxygen activation and CO2 desorption, which will provide hints in constructing optimal surface/interface. coredata.dc:description: The surficial properties of heterogeneous catalysts are vital in determining their catalytic performance. Herein, we take K-CuO x /CeO2 as a typical composite to unveil the decisive role of surficial properties on the adsorption strengths of reactants, configurations of intermediates and desorption of products during CO preferential oxidation. Results show that adding K initially has minimal effect, but too much drastically reduces catalytic performance. Detailed analyses indicate adding K to CuO x /CeO2 catalyst increases the surficial basic sites, which not only inhibits O2 activation and CO2 desorption, but also reduces surface defects, Cu+ species and hydroxy species. Such a vast difference in adsorption behavior and surface species in turn lead to the transformation of intermediates from carboxylates to carbonates. DFT calculations further reveal that the barrier of rate-determining step for CuO x /CeO2 catalyst in carboxyl path is lower than that of K-CuO x /CeO2 in carbonate path, thus rendering a higher catalytic activity of CuO x /CeO2.
